trial_identification.studytitle: Can patient self-management education programs improve outcomes of people with osteoarthritis?
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Can patient self-management education programs improve Health-Related Quality of Life in people with moderate to severe hip or knee osteoarthritis?
trial_identification.secondaryid: National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC): 400210

conditions.healthcondition: Moderate to severe hip or knee osteoarthritis

interventions.interventions: Participants will be recruited from outpatient orthopaedic and rheumatology clinics at Cabrini Hospital, Austin Hospital, The Northern Hospital, Alfred Hospital, Epworth Hospital, Frankston Hospital and Geelong Hospital. Participants will be randomly allocated to either an intervention group or a control group. The intervention group will undergo a 6-week Arthritis Self-Management Program, involving 1 session per week (each session is 2.5 hours) and will also receive an Arthritis Self-Management book.
interventions.comparator: The control group will not undergo the Arthritis Self-Management program but will receive an Arthritis Self-Management book.

primaryOutcome.outcome: The primary outcome is Health-Related Quality of Life (HRQoL) measured using the Assessment of Quality of Life (AQoL) instrument.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: HRQoL will also be measured at baseline, 3 months and 12 months.

secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Measured at baseline, 6 weeks, 3 months and 12 months

secondaryOutcome.outcome: 2. Western Ontario and McMaster Universities Osteoarthritis (WOMAC) Index score.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Measured at baseline, 3 months and 12 months
Measured at baseline, 6 weeks, 3 months and 12 months

secondaryOutcome.outcome: 4. Kessler Psychological Distress (K10) scale score. Measured at baseline, 3 months and 12 months
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Measured at baseline, 3 months and 12 months
Collected at baseline, 3 months and 12 months

secondaryOutcome.outcome: In addition to completing written questionnaires, 100 participants will be asked to undergo up to 2 qualitative interviews by telephone.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: 1. Hip or knee osteoarthritis for which the patient has been referred to or consulted an orthopaedic surgeon or rheumatologist . 2. Able to complete written questionnaires in English 3. A reasonable expectation that the 6 sessions of the Arthritis Self-Management Program can be attended
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: 1. Patients on an orthopaedic waiting list for joint replacement surgery or scheduled joint replacement surgery 2. Cognitive dysfunction 3. Previous participation in an Arthritis Self-Management Program.

trial_design.concealment: Group allocation will be concealed using sealed opaque envelopes to be opened by a research assistant at the Centre for Rheumatic Diseases, The University of Melbourne after receipt of a signed written consent form.
trial_design.sequence: Group allocation will be assigned after stratification by hopsital site according to a computer-generated table of random numbers using an uneven numbers block design. A second randomisation procedure will be used to select 100 participants to participate in qualitative telephone interviews.

fundingsource.fundingname: National Health and Medical Research Council

ethicsAndSummary.summary: The purpose of this study is to investigate the effect of a 6-week patient education program, the Arthritis Self-Management Program, for people with hip or knee osteoarthritis. This study will find out whether the Program improves peoples wellbeing and whether it is good value for money.
